Stem: The model shows a force acting on a car. A second force is applied and the car's motion stops changing. Which model best represents the forces?
Image/Diagram Description: Force diagram showing arrow on car; four answer options showing different force arrow configurations.
Choices: A) [diagram A], B) [diagram B], C) [diagram C], D) [diagram D]
Scenario Justification: Force diagram scenario where students must identify balanced forces from visual models.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Developing and Using Models' — students interpret force diagrams and select the model showing balanced forces.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that when motion stops changing forces must be balanced (equal and opposite).
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (balanced forces → no change in motion) and Patterns.
Key Recommendation: Excellent modeling question. Students must connect force diagrams to motion concepts.

Stem: Which change would most likely create balanced forces in Round Three of tug-of-war?
Image/Diagram Description: Pictures of four rounds of tug-of-war showing different group sizes on each side.
Choices: A) Add four new students to the left side of the rope, B) Replace one student with an adult on each side of the rope, C) Put all the students on the same side of the rope, D) Put one more student on each side of the rope
Scenario Justification: Rich tug-of-war scenario with four rounds of visual data showing different configurations.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — students must analyze the current imbalance and determine what change creates balance.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding of balanced vs. unbalanced forces and how to achieve equilibrium.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (adding force to weaker side → balanced forces).
Key Recommendation: Strong application of balanced/unbalanced forces using a relatable scenario.

Stem: Which example best provides evidence that balanced forces combine to produce a net force of zero?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) A bike speeding up, B) A rocket taking off, C) A book sitting on a table, D) A ball rolling down a ramp
Scenario Justification: Students evaluate which scenario demonstrates balanced forces. Claim-evidence structure.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — selecting evidence that supports a given claim.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of balanced forces producing zero net force.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (balanced forces → no motion change).
Key Recommendation: Good claim-evidence format. Add force diagrams for each scenario to increase complexity.

Stem: Students changed the release distance of the sphere in Newton's cradle. Which statements best describe the purpose for increasing the release distance?
Image/Diagram Description: Newton's cradle diagram with data table showing release distances and resulting movement distances.
Choices: A) to indicate balanced forces are acting on the spheres, B) to determine the types of forces acting on the spheres, C) to measure the strength of the force acting on the spheres, D) to change the direction of the force acting on the spheres, E) to observe the effect of unbalanced forces acting on the spheres
Scenario Justification: Rich investigation scenario with Newton's cradle. Data table showing systematic release distance variation. Students must understand experimental design purpose.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Planning and Carrying Out Investigations' — students analyze why a variable was changed in an investigation. High-level practice.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding relationship between release distance and force strength and the concept of unbalanced forces.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (greater release distance → greater force → greater movement).
Key Recommendation: Excellent investigation question. Students reason about experimental design purpose using data.

Stem: Which evidence from the Newton's cradle investigation demonstrates that the pattern of motion for the spheres is predictable?
Image/Diagram Description: Data table showing number of spheres released vs number that moved on right side.
Choices: A) The spheres eventually stop moving, B) The spheres on the right side can be pulled back, C) The movement of the spheres occurs over different periods of time, D) The movement of the sphere on the right matches the movement of the released spheres
Scenario Justification: Continuation of Newton's cradle investigation. Students identify evidence of predictable patterns.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — identifying which evidence demonstrates predictable patterns from experimental data.
DCI Justification: Requires connecting data patterns to the concept of predictable motion.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (consistent 1:1 relationship between spheres released and spheres that move).
Key Recommendation: Strong data analysis question. Students identify the key pattern from experimental results.

Stem: How many spheres on the right will most likely move if a student releases 4 spheres on the left?
Image/Diagram Description: Same Newton's cradle data table.
Choices: Enter your answer in the box.
Scenario Justification: Prediction task using established data pattern from Newton's cradle investigation.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Using Mathematics and Computational Thinking' — extending a data pattern to make a prediction.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding and extending the pattern that released spheres = moving spheres.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (extending a consistent pattern to predict future outcomes).
Key Recommendation: Excellent prediction question requiring pattern extension from data. Constructed response adds rigor.

Stem: What would most likely happen to the motion of the toy truck if Kobe used twice as much force as Rachel?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram and data table showing toy truck experiment where Rachel pushes from right, Kobe from left; five trial results showing truck staying still when equal force is used.
Choices: A) The toy truck would move towards Kobe, B) The toy truck would move toward Rachel, C) The toy truck would stay still, D) The toy truck would move up
Scenario Justification: Experimental scenario with data table. Students predict what happens when forces become unbalanced.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — using experimental data to predict outcome when a variable changes.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that doubling one force creates unbalanced forces causing motion toward the weaker force.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (unbalanced forces → motion in direction of stronger force).
Key Recommendation: Good prediction from experimental data. Students reason about force imbalance.

Stem: Based on observations in Investigation 1, which statement best describes the interaction between the horseshoe magnet and paper clip?
Image/Diagram Description: Data table showing horseshoe magnet heights and whether paper clip rose to stick to magnet (Yes at 2-12cm, No at 15-30cm).
Choices: A) The horseshoe magnet repels the paper clip when farther away, B) The horseshoe magnet applies more attractive force on the paper clip from nearby than from farther away, C) The paper clip applies more magnetic force on the horseshoe magnet when farther away, D) The paper clip and the horseshoe magnet repel each other at close distances and attract when farther apart
Scenario Justification: Investigation with data table showing magnetic force vs distance. Students analyze the relationship.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — interpreting experimental data about magnetic force and distance.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that magnetic force decreases with distance.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (closer distance → stronger magnetic force) and Patterns (systematic relationship).
Key Recommendation: Strong data analysis question about magnetic force-distance relationship.

Stem: Based on data provided, determine the lowest height at which the paper clip will be unable to rise and stick to the magnet.
Image/Diagram Description: Same data table from Investigation 1.
Choices: A) 8 cm, B) 13 cm, C) 21 cm, D) 27 cm
Scenario Justification: Data interpretation task using the magnetic force investigation data.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — identifying the threshold distance from experimental data.
DCI Justification: Requires reading data table to find where magnetic force becomes insufficient.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (distance threshold → force insufficient to lift clip).
Key Recommendation: Good data interpretation. Students must identify the transition point in experimental data.

Stem: A carpenter wants to use magnets to keep a cabinet door closed and prevent it from hitting a nearby wall. Which diagram shows correct magnet placement?
Image/Diagram Description: Four diagrams showing different magnet configurations on cabinet and wall.
Choices: A) [Diagram A], B) [Diagram B], C) [Diagram C], D) [Diagram D]
Scenario Justification: Engineering design scenario applying magnet properties to solve a practical problem with two constraints.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — evaluating which magnet configuration meets both constraints (hold door closed + prevent wall collision).
DCI Justification: Requires understanding of both attract and repel properties of magnets applied to a real-world problem.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (magnet orientation → attract/repel → meeting design constraints).
Key Recommendation: Excellent engineering application of magnet concepts with dual constraints.

Stem: Alex wants to build a simple game where a toy car moves across a track without being touched. How can you design the game using magnets?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) Use a fan to blow air and push the car along the track, B) Put a wooden block inside the car then use a magnet on a stick to repel the block, C) Put a metal piece on the car and place a magnet at the end of the track to pull the car even though too far away, D) Put a magnet inside the car and use another magnet under the table to move the car
Scenario Justification: Practical problem-solving scenario about using magnetism through a surface.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — evaluating which approach effectively solves the problem given constraints.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of magnetic force through materials. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (magnet → force on magnet in car → car moves) and Structure and Function.
Key Recommendation: Good problem-solving question. Elevate by providing data from testing different approaches.

Stem: Brad and Brian must separate a mixture. Which items can be removed with a magnet and why?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) Iron filings and paperclips because they are magnetic, B) Toothpicks iron filings and bits of notebook paper because all magnetic, C) Broken crayons bits of notebook paper and sand because all magnetic, D) Broken crayons and chocolate chips because they are magnetic
Scenario Justification: Applied scenario about using magnetic properties to separate a mixture.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice beyond recall. Basic application of magnetic properties.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that only iron-containing materials are magnetic.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Add experimental data showing which items were attracted and ask students to explain the pattern.

Stem: Which problem could be solved by a magnet?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) a cupboard door that keeps falling open, B) a backpack that is too heavy, C) a toaster that doesn't work
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Simple identification of a magnetic solution.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recognition level.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of practical magnet applications.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Only 3 answer choices. Add a scenario with constraints and data about different solutions.

Stem: Which order shows the correct life cycle of a butterfly?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) Egg → Chrysalis → Caterpillar → Butterfly, B) Egg → Caterpillar → Chrysalis → Butterfly, C) Caterpillar → Egg → Chrysalis → Butterfly, D) Caterpillar → Chrysalis → Egg → Butterfly
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure sequence recall of butterfly metamorphosis.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Ordering memorized sequence.
DCI Justification: Tests life cycle stage knowledge. Recall level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide unfamiliar insect life cycle data and ask students to identify stages from evidence.

Stem: The diagram shows four numbered stages in the life cycle of a ladybug. Which process must occur between stage 3 and stage 4?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing four stages of ladybug life cycle.
Choices: A) birth, B) death, C) development, D) reproduction
Scenario Justification: Visual life cycle diagram. Students identify the process between two stages.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — reasoning about what biological process connects two life cycle stages.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of what occurs between pupa and adult stages (metamorphic development).
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (sequential life cycle stages with specific processes between them).
Key Recommendation: Good diagram-based question. Add data about developmental timing to deepen analysis.

Stem: A class grew tomato plants indoors. The plants grew but did not produce tomatoes. Why?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) The class needs to wait longer and the plants will eventually grow tomatoes, B) The windows blocked the rays from the Sun that the plants need to grow tomatoes, C) By keeping the plants inside pollinators such as bees were unable to pollinate the plants, D) In the classroom the plants were not placed close enough to another plant for reproduction to happen
Scenario Justification: Classroom plant investigation scenario. Students explain why indoor plants did not fruit.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — reasoning about why an expected outcome did not occur based on biological knowledge.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding of pollination as necessary for fruit production — goes beyond simple recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (no pollinators → no pollination → no fruit).
Key Recommendation: Good reasoning question about pollination. Could add data on indoor vs outdoor plant fruit production.

Stem: How does living in a herd help wild horses?
Image/Diagram Description: Image of a herd of wild horses.
Choices: A) It is hard for predators to catch horses, B) It is harder for predators to pick out one horse to eat, C) More horses looking for food make it harder for horses to find food, D) It is easy for the horses to find shelter in the storm
Scenario Justification: Image-based scenario about herd behavior benefits.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Basic recall of group behavior benefit.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of how group living protects individuals from predation.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data comparing predation rates for solitary vs herd animals.

Stem: How does staying with the herd instead of going off by themselves help the female caribou?
Image/Diagram Description: Passage about tundra animals (caribou and musk ox) with images.
Choices: A) In a large herd more individuals can keep watch for predators than can a lone individual, B) In a large herd more individuals are able to hunt for prey than can a lone individual, C) In a large herd young caribou can find food by their own, D) In a large herd fewer individuals are likely to become sick or injured
Scenario Justification: Rich passage with detailed information about caribou and musk ox behavior in tundra. Students must use passage evidence.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — using passage evidence to identify the benefit of herd behavior for female caribou specifically.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of group behavior benefits. Requires connecting passage details to the specific question.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (herd → more watchers → better predator detection).
Key Recommendation: Good passage-based question. Already has rich context. Could add comparative data.

Stem: Which best describes how raspberries get their color?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) Raspberry color is an inherited trait that varies among raspberry plants, B) Raspberry color is controlled by the amount of sugar that raspberry plants produce, C) Raspberry color is controlled by the amount of sunlight that raspberry plants receive, D) Raspberry color is an inherited trait that changes when raspberry plants have a disease
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario about yellow raspberries from red raspberry parents. Evaluation of inheritance explanations.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — reasoning about how trait variation occurs through inheritance.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of inherited traits and variation in offspring.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (offspring traits vary but are inherited from parents).
Key Recommendation: Good concept. Add breeding data showing trait distributions across generations.

Stem: A scientist studies a plant species with different-sized flowers. Plants are separated into three groups for breeding. Based on information what can be concluded about flower size?
Image/Diagram Description: Data table showing breeding results: large×large → large, small×small → small, mixed group → varying sizes.
Choices: A) Flower size occurs randomly, B) Flower size is an inherited trait, C) Flower size always changes as the plants grow, D) Flower size is determined only by the environment
Scenario Justification: Breeding experiment with data table showing trait inheritance patterns across generations.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students analyze breeding data to draw conclusions about inheritance.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding inheritance by analyzing data from controlled breeding experiments.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (breeding data shows consistent inheritance patterns).
Key Recommendation: Excellent data-based inheritance question. Students analyze breeding results to draw conclusions.

Stem: Which trait is least likely to be passed on from parents to children?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) color blindness, B) eye color, C) blood type, D) childhood scar
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Simple identification of a non-inherited trait.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall/recognition.
DCI Justification: Tests ability to distinguish inherited from acquired traits.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on parent-offspring trait comparisons and ask students to identify which traits show inheritance patterns.

Stem: The characteristics of trees can be influenced by the environment and by inheritance. The height of a tree in a forest is the result of what?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) the environment, B) inheritance, C) both the environment and inheritance
Scenario Justification: Multi-part question about environmental vs inherited influences on tree characteristics.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — reasoning about whether tree height is environmental, inherited, or both.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that some traits are influenced by both genes and environment.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (both genetic potential and environmental conditions → tree height).
Key Recommendation: Good concept. Could provide tree height data from same species in different environments to support reasoning.
